ЁЯСС
Resurgence

The resurgence of Chola power began with Vijayalaya Chola's capture of Thanjavur in the 9th century. This marked the beginning of the 'Imperial Chola' era, which transformed South Indian history. Emperors like Rajaraja I and Rajendra I made it an all-India power.

ЁЯМК
From the Ganges to Across the Seas

Rajendra Chola I sent his armies north to the Ganges River (after which he assumed the title 'Gangaikonda') and dispatched his navy against Srivijaya (Indonesia/Malaysia). This is the only instance in Indian history of an Indian king conquering overseas territories. The Indian Ocean, in a way, became a 'Chola Sea'.

ЁЯПЧя╕П
Cultural Zenith

The Cholas took Dravidian architecture to new heights (e.g., the Brihadeeswarar Temple). Bronze sculptures of Nataraja (Dancing Shiva) are world-famous symbols of Chola art. Their local administration (Ur and Sabha) was a model of autonomy and efficiency.
